results.title: The Selling of Attention Deficit Disorder
results.abstract: Diagnoses have soared as makers of the drugs used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder have found success with a two-decade marketing campaign.

media.caption: “This is a concoction to justify the giving out of medication at unprecedented and unjustifiable levels,” Keith Conners, a psychologist and early advocate for recognition of A.D.H.D., said of the rising rates of diagnosis of the disorder.
media.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

media.caption: Roger Griggs, who introduced Adderall in 1994 before ads portraying medication as a way to improve grades and behavior were allowed, said, “There’s no way on God’s green earth we would ever promote” stimulants directly to consumers.
media.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

results.title: A Formula for Happiness
results.abstract: Social scientists have determined three sources of supreme contentment: genes, events and values.

media.copyright: Brian Rea

results.byline: By PAUL A. OFFIT and SARAH ERUSH
results.title: Skip the Supplements
results.abstract: Dietary supplements: mislabeled, contaminated and probably useless.

media.copyright: Melody Newcomb

results.title: Even Gifted Students Can’t Keep Up
results.abstract: With its best students far behind their foreign peers, America needs new ideas to nurture their talent and produce new innovators.

media.copyright: EKTA

results.title: Solving the Shortage in Primary Care Doctors
results.abstract: Congress and the hospitals have established a residency system that doesn’t train the doctors Americans need most.

media.copyright: Morgan Schweitzer

results.title: Scientists Turn Their Gaze Toward Tiny Threats to Great Lakes
results.abstract: Scientists have worried about plastic debris in the oceans for decades, but focused on enormous accumulations. More recently, the question of smaller bits has gained attention.

media.copyright: Brendan Bannon for The New York Times

results.title: The Great War’s Ominous Echoes
results.abstract: If we cannot determine how World War I happened, how can we hope to avoid another such catastrophe?
des_facet: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

media.copyright: Robert G. Fresson

results.title: Seduced by Naples
results.abstract: More than Florence, Rome or Venice, the author argues, it is Naples that is one of the most romantic cities in the world.

media.caption: A view of the city from the former monastery of San Martino.
media.copyright: Giulio Piscitelli for The New York Times

media.caption: Looking at Caravaggio's “The Flagellation.”
media.copyright: Giulio Piscitelli for The New York Times

media.caption: A marble skull in the courtyard of San Martino.
media.copyright: Giulio Piscitelli for The New York Times

media.caption: Vegetables for sale in the Quartieri Spagnoli.
media.copyright: Giulio Piscitelli for The New York Times

media.caption: Mount Vesuvius looms over the city.
media.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

media.caption: The Gesù Nuovo church.
media.copyright: Giulio Piscitelli for The New York Times

results.title: Bloomberg Focuses on Rest (as in Rest of the World)
results.abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will take much of his City Hall team with him as he creates a consulting group to help him reshape cities around the globe.

media.caption: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg with his girlfriend, Diana L. Taylor, at an Association for a Better New York event. Mr. Bloomberg’s consulting group will include many of his best-known deputies.
media.copyright: Angel Franco/The New York Times

media.caption: George A. Fertitta, left, will run Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s new consulting group.
media.copyright: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

results.title: An Alternative to Giving Up the Car Keys
results.abstract: The number of older drivers on the road is growing, but technology and training could keep them behind the wheel safely for longer.

media.caption: Anne Hegberg, left, an occupational therapist who specializes in helping drivers compensate for any lost skills, with a client, JoAnn Mantzke, 80.
media.copyright: John Gress for The New York Times

media.caption: Donna Stressel, a driving specialist, evaluating the driving skills of Robert Cullon, 80. She found him fit to take the wheel.
media.copyright: Charlie Samuels for The New York Times

results.title: Cook Islands, a Paradise of Untouchable Assets
results.abstract: These flyspeck islands in the Pacific have the reputation of being a place where assets can be hidden from business partners, litigants or former spouses.

media.copyright: Glynis Sweeny

media.caption: A recent data leak revealed that R. Allen Stanford, who was convicted of running a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, held a Cook trust.
media.copyright: Richard Carson/Reuters

media.caption: Dr. Michael Kamrava, a fertility doctor who lost his license in the “Octomom” case, also had assets in the Cook Islands.
media.copyright: Nick Ut/Associated Press

media.caption: Denise Rich, ex-wife of the disgraced trader Marc Rich, had a Cook trust worth more than $100 million.
media.copyright: Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images for Princess Grace Foundation

results.title: The Catholics Still in Exile
results.abstract: Pope Francis’ words are gentle, but the church’s treatment of some employees remains harsh, impeding the outreach to disaffected Catholics.

media.copyright: Ben Wiseman

media.caption: Frank Bruni
media.copyright: Earl Wilson/The New York Times

results.title: Remembering Days of Miracle and Wonder
results.abstract: Paul Simon recalls how the spirit of Nelson Mandela infused the music of “Graceland” and his tours with South African musicians.

media.caption: Nelson Mandela and Paul Simon in 1992.
media.copyright: Anna Zieminski/LGI

media.caption: Paul Simon’s 1986 album “Graceland” was followed by a 1987 tour, including this show in Harare, Zimbabwe.
media.copyright: Penny Tweedie/CORBIS

results.title: Japan’s Top Voice: High, Polite and on the Phone
results.abstract: The annual All-Japan Phone-Answering Competition for office workers is a closely watched contest that some say reiterates the stereotype of women in clerical positions.

media.caption: Mika Otani and more than 12,000 other Japanese competed in a telephone-answering contest, a showcase of cultural etiquette.
media.copyright: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times

media.caption: A record 12,613 office workers sought to compete this year in the annual All-Japan Phone-Answering Competition in Sendai.

results.title: Leaked! Harvard’s Grading Rubric
results.abstract: A review of the grading guidelines rubric at Harvard (hint: an A is usually right, or an A+).

results.title: The Daughter Theory
results.abstract: Does raising girls make parents conservative?

media.caption: Ross Douthat
media.copyright: Josh Haner/The New York Times

results.title: The 10 Best Books of 2013
results.abstract: The year’s best books, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.

media.copyright: Todd St. John

results.title: A Utah Law Prohibiting Polygamy Is Weakened
results.abstract: A federal judge struck down parts of Utah’s anti-polygamy law as unconstitutional in a case brought by a star of “Sister Wives,” the reality television show.

results.title: What Tech Hasn’t Learned From Urban Planning
results.abstract: Companies flock to cities talking of community, then proceed to isolate themselves from the urban experience.

media.caption: Allison Arieff
media.copyright: Jim Wilson for The New York Times

media.caption: With cafes and sandwich shops shuttered, only "the taster," one-time symbol of Hills Brothers Coffee, still has access to coffee in Hills Plaza.
Once a fairly vibrant pedestrian space, this mostly deserted plaza now feels more like something rendered by de Chirico.
The "ballet of the good sidewalk always replete with new observations," as described by Jane Jacobs, is nowhere in evidence in front of Twitter's headquarters.

results.title: At Paris Brasseries, Cuisine to Match the Scene
results.abstract: In recent years, the city’s brasseries have gained a reputation for mediocrity. But at these four spots, diners can find both a lively atmosphere and satisfying food.

media.caption: Diners at Lazare, a new spot in the Eighth Arrondissement.
media.copyright: Ed Alcock for The New York Times

media.caption: The chef Eric Frechon.
media.copyright: Ed Alcock for The New York Times

media.caption: Steak tartare at La Rotonde.
media.copyright: Ed Alcock for The New York Times

media.caption: Mini Palais opened in 2011.
media.copyright: Ed Alcock for The New York Times
